Title:
Molecular phylogeny of the genus Exorista Meigen (Diptera:
Tachinidae), with a discussion of evolutionary pattern of host use
Abstract:
Members of the genus Exorista are parasitic on different
insect orders: Lepidoptera, Hymenoptera, Mantodea and Orthoptera.
Phylogenetic relationships among subgenera and species of Exorista were
inferred with four nuclear (Tpi, white, 18S and 28S) and four
mitochondrial DNA (16S, 12S, ND5 and CO1) genes in maximum parsimony,
maximum likelihood and Bayesian Markov chain Monte Carlo analyses. The
combination of the different genes is compared and these results are
nearly concordant. Based on the molecular tree generated by a
concatenated data, the genus Exorista is non-monophyletic and the
morphological traits supporting clades within this genus are estimated.
In addition, the evolutionary patterns of the host shifts in this genus
are discussed based on the molecular tree by optimizing host information
under maximum likelihood approach. The ancestral state of the tribe
Exoristini (excluding Ctenophorinia and Phorinia) was the parasitism of
the order Lepidoptera, although hosts of some present species are
unknown. The transition to the Hymenoptera occurred in the clade of
subgenus Adenia and the ancestral state of subgenus Spixomyia is
equivocal because there is little information available on the hosts in
members of subclade A (E. hyalipennis group).
